bibliography.title: MuRIL: Multilingual Representations for Indian Languages
bibliography.authors: Simran Khanuja, Diksha Bansal, Sarvesh Mehtani et al.
bibliography.annotation: The candidate paper is relevant to the intellectual context of the topic. The paper discusses the challenges faced by low-resource languages, particularly Indian languages, in current language models. It then proposes a new strategy, MuRIL, which is a language model specifically built for Indian languages. This strategy involves augmenting monolingual corpora with translated document pairs to provide supervised cross-lingual signals during training. The paper's focus on strategies for improving language model performance for low-resource languages aligns directly with the topic.

bibliography.title: English in LLMs: The Role of AI in Avoiding Cultural Homogenization
bibliography.annotation:
Relevant.

The candidate paper is relevant to the topic as it discusses strategies for preserving linguistic diversity and reducing the dominance of English in large language models (LLMs). The paper suggests that governments and international bodies should develop regulations to support linguistic pluralism and protect cultures in the digital sphere. It also discusses the creation and deployment of smaller models specifically adapted to local languages as a strategy to preserve linguistic nuance and reduce reliance on a single standard language. Other strategies mentioned include community-driven data curation, impact assessments of model deployment, and policies to promote open-access partnerships and linguistic sovereignty. These strategies could be applied to low-resource languages to help preserve and potentially revitalize them.
